Appeal by special leave from the Award dated December 29, 1958 of the Industrial Tribunal, Delhi in I. D. No. 36 of 1957 published in the Delhi Gazette dated 5th March, 1959. B. Pai and I. N. Shroff, for the Appellant. K. Ramamurthi, B. K. Garg, S. C. Agarwala, and D. P. Singh, for the Respondent 1.
This appeal by special leave, arises out of an industrial dispute between the Birla Cotton Spinning and Weaving Mills Limited  hereinafter called the appellant  and its workmen.

concepts.interpretation: Standardisation scheme is an integrated whole requiring wages above the standardised level to be reduced to fit the scheme; tribunals may protect individual higher wages as personal pay subject to three conditions: no further raises by management, absorption in increments if applicable, no succession to protected pay by successors.

issues.text: Whether wages of mistries and line jobbers require to be increased and standardised, and what directions are necessary

anchor.surface_text: This appeal by special leave, arises out of an industrial dispute between the Birla Cotton Spinning and Weaving Mills Limited  hereinafter called the appellant  and its workmen. A large number of matters were referred for adjudication to the industrial tribunal but in the present appeal we are companycerned with two, namely, ii  whether the wages require to be increased and standardised,

issues.text: Whether any of the workmen doing the work of fancy jobbers should be designated and paid accordingly

anchor.surface_text: namely, ii  whether the wages require to be increased and standardised, and what directions are necessary in this respect, and  ii  whether any of the workmen doing the work of fancy jobbers should be designated and paid accordingly.

holdings.text: The Dulat award of 1951 does not bar the competence of the present reference.

anchor.surface_text: Re. i . The question whether the Dulat award of 1951 stood in the way of the present reference being competent was considered by this Court in the earlier case referred to above and was rejected. It was then pointed out that the Dulat award had held that there was no justification for delaying standardisation and had ordered the parties to work out a scheme taking the Bombay award No. 1 as the working model.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows earlier Supreme Court judgment; 1951 scheme agreement not part of award and not a settlement u/s 2(p) ID Act so s.19(2) inapplicable.

holdings.text: Workmen designated as assistant fancy jobbers are actually fancy jobbers and should be designated and paid as such.

anchor.surface_text: Re. ii We are of opinion that the tribunal was right in holding that it was only shortly before the reference that those workmen who used to be called fancy jobbers began to be designated as assistant fancy jobbers. The tribunal has considered the entire evidence on this point and we are in agreement with the view expressed by it, namely, that the assistant fancy jobbers should be designated as fancy jobbers as before and the recent innovation calling them assistant fancy jobbers was only a device to depress the status of this class of workmen.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Agrees with tribunal after review of entire evidence; recent redesignation a device to lower status.

holdings.text: Tribunal cannot mechanically apply Bombay standardisation scheme without evidence on its working, local Delhi conditions, and differences from Bombay; must reconsider after allowing evidence.

anchor.surface_text: Re. iii . It appears that the tribunal merely followed its earlier award in ID 52 of 1957 when it proceeded to apply the Bombay standardisation scheme to mistries and line jobbers as well as fancy jobbers. That award, as we have pointed out, was set aside by this Court in the earlier judgment on various grounds.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows earlier judgment setting aside prior award; refusal to hear evidence on scheme's working violates fairness; Delhi mills not applying scheme to mistries/jobbers; work comparison needed for categories like fancy jobbers.

holdings.text: Tribunal cannot delegate resolution of anomalies from standardisation scheme to joint committee; must adjudicate itself, possibly with assessors.

anchor.surface_text: Re. iv . As to the direction by the tribunal that a joint committee should be appointed to go into what is called,anomalies, it is enough to refer to what was said by this Court in the earlier judgment where a similar direction had been made. It was pointed out there that by making the direction the tribunal had left a part of the dispute to be resolved by the parties themselves,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows earlier Supreme Court judgment rejecting similar delegation.

holdings.text: Tribunal direction protecting all existing higher wages/post-scheme is invalid against standardisation principle; protects posts not individuals.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Standardisation scheme integrated whole requires reducing high wages; tribunal direction protects wages/posts allowing succession claims.

holdings.text: Tribunal may protect individual workmen drawing higher wages at scheme introduction as personal pay subject to three conditions: no future management raises, absorption in increments if applicable, no entitlement for successors.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Balances standardisation with justice; distinguishes Daru case (post-scheme management raises impermissible); protection only personal, non-heritable, with specified limits.

holdings.text: Appeal allowed; tribunal award partly set aside; remanded for rehearing on wage increase/standardisation for mistries, line-jobbers, fancy jobbers allowing further evidence.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Cumulative effect of errors in tribunal award on key issues requires fresh adjudication per indicated principles.

precedents.citation: The Management of Birla Cotton Spinning and Weaving Mills Ltd. v. Its workmen 1 A.I.R. 1961 S.C. 1179

anchor.surface_text: is reported in The Management of Birla Cotton Spinning and Weaving Mills Ltd. v. Its workmen 1 . This companyrt had set aside the earlier award and sent the case back to the tribunal to proceed in the manner indicated in the judgment. We are told that matter has ended in a companypromise between the parties. The claim of the workmen companycerned in the present A.I.R. 1961 S.C. 1179.

precedents.case_name: Management of Birla Cotton Spinning and Weaving Mills Ltd. v. Its Workmen
precedents.cited_proposition: Dulat award does not bar reference; tribunal must properly consider evidence on Bombay standardisation scheme before applying it; no direction for joint committee; principle that standardisation scheme requires reduction of higher wages
precedents.cited_holding: It cannot be disputed that when a standardisation scheme comes into force it is an integrated whole and may sometime result in some categories of workmen getting less than what they were getting before.

precedents.citation: Daru v. Ahmedabad Spinning and Manufacturing Company limited. 1 1955 1 L. L. G. 355

anchor.surface_text: Reliance in this connection has been placed on behalf of the appellant on Daru v. Ahmedabad Spinning and Manufacturing Company limited. 1 In that case the principles governing a standardisation scheme were considered by the Bombay High Court considering the report of the Textile Labour Inquiry Committee and also the book of Dr. D. R. Gadgil on Regulation of wages and other Problems of Industrial Labour in India.

precedents.case_name: Daru v. Ahmedabad Spinning and Manufacturing Company Ltd.
precedents.cited_proposition: Principles of standardisation scheme require equal wages for same work, including reduction of higher wages paid after scheme introduction to scheme level
precedents.cited_holding: where higher wages had been paid than those fixed in the standardisation scheme they should be reduced to that level

justification_sets.label: Natural Justice - Audi Alteram Partem support

anchor.surface_text: We therefore allow the appeal and set aside partly the order of the tribunal with respect to certain matters with which we have dealt in the course of this judgment and direct that the tribunal should rehear the reference and reconsider in the light of this judgment and the earlier judgment what should be its award with

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal allowed; tribunal's award partly set aside (including directions on Bombay scheme application, joint committee, and protection of higher wages); matter remanded to tribunal for fresh consideration on whether wages of mistries, line-jobbers and fancy jobbers require increase and standardisation
directions: tribunal should rehear the reference and reconsider in the light of this judgment and the earlier judgment what should be its award with respect to mistries, line-jobbers and fancy jobbers in connection with the term of reference: Whether the wages require to be increased and standardised, and what directions are necessary in this respect
Parties will be at liberty to lead such further evidence on all matters sent back for reconsideration as they think fit

edges.explanation: Holding that Dulat award does not bar directly addresses issue of whether award stood in way of reference

anchor.surface_text: Re. i . The question whether the Dulat award of 1951 stood in the way of the present reference being competent was considered by this Court in the earlier case referred to above and was rejected. It was then pointed out that the Dulat award had held that there was no justification for delaying standardisation and had ordered the parties to work out a scheme taking the Bombay award No. 1 as the working model.

We therefore allow the appeal and set aside partly the order of the tribunal with respect to certain matters with which we have dealt in the course of this judgment and direct that the tribunal should rehear the reference and reconsider in the light of this judgment and the earlier judgment what should be its award with

Re. ii We are of opinion that the tribunal was right in holding that it was only shortly before the reference that those workmen who used to be called fancy jobbers began to be designated as assistant fancy jobbers. The tribunal has considered the entire evidence on this point and we are in agreement with the view expressed by it, namely, that the assistant fancy jobbers should be designated as fancy jobbers as before and the recent innovation calling them assistant fancy jobbers was only a device to depress the status of this class of workmen.

We therefore allow the appeal and set aside partly the order of the tribunal with respect to certain matters with which we have dealt in the course of this judgment and direct that the tribunal should rehear the reference and reconsider in the light of this judgment and the earlier judgment what should be its award with
s than fixed in the standardisation scheme to any one employed thereafter. On the other hand, it is companytended for the appellant that when a standa

anchor.surface_text: Re. iii . It appears that the tribunal merely followed its earlier award in ID 52 of 1957 when it proceeded to apply the Bombay standardisation scheme to mistries and line jobbers as well as fancy jobbers. That award, as we have pointed out, was set aside by this Court in the earlier judgment on various grounds.

We therefore allow the appeal and set aside partly the order of the tribunal with respect to certain matters with which we have dealt in the course of this judgment and direct that the tribunal should rehear the reference and reconsider in the light of this judgment and the earlier judgment what should be its award with
ndividual workmen who may be getting more wages than those fixed in the standardisation scheme when it companyes into force and this direction is comp

edges.explanation: Holding rules tribunal cannot delegate resolution of anomalies to joint committee, directly addressing the issue of whether it could direct such appointment.

anchor.surface_text: Re. iv . As to the direction by the tribunal that a joint committee should be appointed to go into what is called,anomalies, it is enough to refer to what was said by this Court in the earlier judgment where a similar direction had been made. It was pointed out there that by making the direction the tribunal had left a part of the dispute to be resolved by the parties themselves,

We therefore allow the appeal and set aside partly the order of the tribunal with respect to certain matters with which we have dealt in the course of this judgment and direct that the tribunal should rehear the reference and reconsider in the light of this judgment and the earlier judgment what should be its award with
